Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Extending the Range of Applicability of Density-Functional Methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
Adam Wasserman of Purdue University is supported by a CAREER award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry division to develop and apply electronic-structure methods that extend the reach of quantum-chemical approaches based on Density Functional Theory. The methods being investigated provide a new framework for developing and testing approximate density functionals for accurate calculations of ground and excited electronic states of molecules, including metastable ones. Applications include molecular dissociation, long-range charge-transfer excitations, and conductance through molecular wires - all cases where the need of accurate Kohn-Sham potentials is circumvented in the new framework by the calculation of appropriate partition potentials, a novel concept that should also prove useful in understanding chemical bonding from a non-traditional perspective. Its time-dependent extension will facilitate our understanding and teaching of modern spectroscopy and molecular electronics.

Underlying most of chemistry is the notion that the energy of two bonded fragments is lower than the sum of the energies of the isolated fragments. The difference between those two energies can be calculated accurately for any pair of fragments using the algorithms that Prof. Wasserman and his research group are developing, supported by this grant. They are implementing the new algorithms into large broadly-available quantum-chemistry codes for the benefit of the scientific community at large. They are also developing pedagogical tools to facilitate the dissemination of scientific advances in the field of electronic-structure theory, using existing resources available at Purdue University. In addition, they are increasing the involvement of Hispanic minorities by organizing scientific events that promote Hispanic participation in science research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We developed and applied novel electronic-structure methods to overcome some of the limitations of state-of-the-art quantum-chemical calculations based on Density Functional Theory. The most important outcomes are listed below:

  • We developed a density-functional method for calculating the energies and lifetimes of electronic molecular resonances. This method is relevant to reactions involving metastable states and electron transport through molecular junctions.  In the new formalism, now called Density Functional Resonance Theory (DFRT), the central variable is a complex density that encodes both the energy and lifetime of the lowest metastable state of the system. We showed that as the particle number of the open system crosses an integer, the exact exchange-correlation potential of DFRT experiences a discontinuous jump. This jump is purely real for integers lower than the maximum number of electrons that the system can bind, but it develops a non-zero imaginary component at that number. The real part of the jump is positive, the imaginary part is negative, and the magnitude of the jump is larger than would have been expected from standard KS-DFT.
  • We demonstrated the feasibility of fully self-consistent DFRT by calculating ionization rates of atoms with exact exchange and an analytically-continued local-density approximation. In related work, we analyzed the e?ect of exchange-correlation asymptotics on adiabatic time-dependent DFT calculations of high-harmonic spectra and investigated the e?ect of pi-donation on the excited-state lifetimes of Pt(II)-terpyridine complexes in solution.
  • We derived a new exact condition for ground-state DFT. The new identity is useful for non-integer electron numbers because it suggests how the integer discontinuities of any spin-density functional approximation can be restored. We proved how a constrained search that leads to the correct linear dependence of the energy on the number of electrons and spins can solve the problem of missing derivative discontinuities in approximate DFT. The new functionals for non-integer N are especially useful for fragment-based formulations of DFT such as Partition-DFT.
  • We proposed a new, formally exact, fragment-based formulation of time-dependent density functional theory. We proved that for a given time-dependent Hamiltonian, initial state, and choice of fragmentation of the external potential, there is a unique single-particle potential (the “time-dependent partition potential”) that, when added to each of the preselected fragment potentials, forces the fragment densities to evolve in such a way that their sum equals the correct molecular density at all times. We derived an exact relationship between the time-dependent partition potential and the total density and provided explicit numerical illustrations. The formalism was also extended to allow for time-dependent fractional charges on the fragments, relevant for TDDFT calculations of charge-transfer processes.
  • We developed a new multilevel optimization method to perform density-to-potential inversions in ground-state DFT and time-dependent DFT. The method treats each inversion as an optimization problem with a partial di?erential equation constraint, and it is controlled by error estimates. As far as we know, it is the only approach to the problem that does not solve an expensive eigenvalue problem at each iteration.

The grant led directly to the Ph.D. degrees of three graduate students. It also partially supported the graduate work of one student toward his M.S. degree, and of two of my current graduate students.

In parallel to these research activities, The PI led several initiatives to strengthen the scienti?c connections between Purdue and Colombia.
